_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





Accidental Release Prevention Policies 

Cascades Tissue will work to prevent accidental releases of toxic or flammable substances that could result in a safety hazard to the public or to the workers at the mill.  Cascades will work with OSHA, U.S. EPA, and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) contacts, including both fire department HAZMAT and the Eau Claire Emergency Government office, to minimize the potential for any accidental release and to help assure that the mill is prepared to respond in the event of an accidental release.  The emphasis of this Risk Management Plan is on the regulated substances identified within the federal regulations.  However, Cascades Tissue has procedures in place to help minimize the chance of accidents related to other potentially hazardous substances stored or handled on site.



If an accidental release were to occur, it is the policy of Cascades Tissue to notify the appropriate emergency contacts.  The City of Eau Claire has a private company that has a HAZMAT response unit that acts as a primary responder in the event of a release of ammonia. Cascades Tissue would use their emergency response plan as a guide to direct the company's response. The facility maintains a response plan to cover potential releases of ammonia as required by the RMP rules.





Description of Facility and Regulated Substance(s)



Cascades Tissue operates a pulp and paper mill on-site producing paper from recycled paper of various types.  Aqueous ammonia is stored on-site in excess of the threshold value of 10,000 lbs., originally included under the Risk Management Plan (RMP) listing rule.  Ammonia is used as a nitrogen source for the wastewater treatment plant.  



Based on a screening review of potentially affected chemical and flammable substances within the offsite consequence Analysis (OCA) only the ammonia storage needed to be included in the RMP, as a regulated process.  Cascades tissue stores a maximum of 18,500

pounds of ammonia in a dedicated storage tank.  For several years, dating back to the time of the original RMP submittal all ammonia storage has been in an aqueous form.  The related modeled distance to the listed 0.14 g/l endpoint of concern for ammonia now extends to the near proximity of the mill.



Several other substances were reviewed within the Offsite Consequence Analysis report as being exempt from listing within the RMP, either because stored quantities are too small to be included or because the substance stored is not a highly toxic or flammable substance listed in the RMP rules.  The mill maintains appropriate records of these other chemicals to demonstrate the exempt status and to assure that general response actions can be implemented for all chemicals of concern in the event of an accidental release.











Worst-Case Release Scenario Description



The worst-case release scenario modeling included the following:



Substance    Scenario            Treatment

    Ammonia    Release to concrete berm    Winds at 1.5 m/s, nighttime F stability class



The worst-case scenarios modeled meet the specifications described in the updated April 2004 Off-site Consequence Analysis Guidance and revised 40 CFR Part 68 (the RMP rules).  Worst-case scenario modeling uses highest air temperatures and associated stored ammonia temperature.





Alternative Release Scenario Description



The Alternative release scenario was selected by evaluating several more typical events and considering the resulting impact with more typical release rates and atmospheric conditions.  The Alternative release scenario was identified using the more conservative of the evaluated scenarios.  The Alternative scenarios included the following:



Substance    Scenario             Treatment

Ammonia    Release to concrete berm     Winds at 4.56 m/s, daytime D stability class

                            

The alternative case uses typical circumstances using 30-year average conditions for July (the warmest month) from the Eau Claire Na

tional Weather Service reporting station.  A detailed review of the 1999 offsite consequence analysis resulted in only minor revisions to the technical descriptions.  Updated population data were incorporated into the 2004 RMP renewal, to meet U.S. EPA guidance.  The 2014 Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) incorporates updated population densities, updated annually using the US Census data for Eau Claire, WI.  Actual values were available through 2010 calculated using extrapolations from the previous period.  A copy of the US Census bureau data for annual estimates of the metropolitan statistical area for Eau Claire (2000 - 2008) is contained in the appendix of the OCA.  The data supports a minor incidental decrease in population but a no change assumption is used here for OCA modeling.





Results of Off-site Consequence Analysis



The Off-site Consequence Analysis resulted in the following predicted distances to the endpoints and population potentially affected:

                

                    Distance to Endpoint (mi.)    Residential Population

    Worst-case Scenario

        Ammonia            0.10                    98



    Alternative Scenario

        Ammonia            0.03                      9



The estimated residential population potentially affected is derived using procedures described in EPA's Off-site Consequence Analysis Guidance.  These procedures conservatively include the entire area inside of a circle described using the storage vessel at the center and the distance to the endpoint as the radius.  Our analysis for the 2014 analysis shows that the critical values related to the ammonia storage have not changed.  In addition, the modeling approach previously used is reviewed as providing acceptable results, based on methods previously used.  Since typical events affect only a relatively narrow sector of this circle, and only a portion of the population would be present at the time, this estimate clearly represents an upper bound for the potentially impacted residential population.



General Accidental Release Program an

d Prevention Steps



Cascades Tissue complies with EPA's Accident Prevention Provisions set forth in 40 CFR Part 68 and applicable state and local codes and regulations. Related discussion on the prevention initiatives is provided with the data elements in Section 8 of this plan.



Five-year Accident History



No reportable incidents related to ammonia storage have occurred in the past five years.





Emergency Response Program



In the event of an emergency involving regulated ammonia storage Cascades Tissue will notify the Eau Claire Fire Department HAZMAT team or the Eau Claire LEPC as appropriate.  The emergency response plan (prepared for chemical releases under 40 CFR Part 68) will be used for response activity guidance by Cascades Tissue.  Because Cascades Tissue is not a primary responder to any ammonia release, no formal classroom training for response plans (HAZWOPER, 40-hr, etc.) is required.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The RMP was reviewed and minor technical changes incorporated into the plan to meet the 2014 guidance provided by U.S. EPA and updated contact and dates for recent relevant activities.  There were only minor changes completed to the contents of the response and prevention plan and associated OCA and RMP under this renewal to the RMP.  The contact information was reviewed and made current. 



No new changes to the safety plans are anticipated.
